div.sent: All the substances found in the world are classified into elements and compounds.
A molecule is composed of two or more atoms.
In the present chapter we shall learn about symbol, formula and valency of elements and compounds.
Chemists have devised a system to express the name of elements in an abbreviated form.
In this system an elements is represented by first one or two letters of its English or Latin name.
A symbol is an abbreviation for the full name of an element.
For example, Hydrogen is represented by H; Oxygen by O; Nitrogen by N, etc.
Generally the first letter of the English name of an element in capital is used to represent its symbol.

Out of these, one element may be denoted by the initial letter of its name, e.g.
Some elements are represented by an initial letter or first two letters of its Latin names.
But there are some exceptions also.
The symbol represents shortened name of an element such as- Hydrogen H, Oxygen O, Sodium Na.
The symbol denotes one atom of the element.
For example, H is written for one atom of hydrogen;
O stands for one atom of oxygen;
C stands for one atom of carbon and Na for one atom of sodium, etc.
Symbol of an element represents the atomic mass of that element.
For example, H represents 1 part by mass of hydrogen and O represents 16 parts by mass of oxygen, etc.
The symbolic representation of molecules of elements or compounds is called the formula.
In writing the formula of an element, the symbol of it is written with the number of atoms of the element present in the molecule.
Therefore, their formula are H2, O2, N2, Cl2, respectively.
The formulas of ozone, sulphur and phosphorous are O3, S6 and P4 respectively.
Again, the molecules of sodium, potassium, copper, helium, argon, etc contain one atom each.
The molecule of a compound consists of atoms of more than one element.
So, the combined atoms are not the same in this molecule.
Thus one molecule of water consists of 2 atoms of hydrogen and 1 atom of oxygen.
So the formula of water is written as H2O.
Hence the whole number of oxygen atom is not written to express the formula of a water molecule.
A formula indicates a definite substance.
Such as, H2O represents water.
A formula indicates the elements that a compound is composed of.
For example, the formula NaCl indicates that it is composed of sodium and chlorine elements.
A formula represents one molecule of a definite substance.
For example one molecule of sodium chloride is represented by NaCl.
A formula indicates how many atoms of each element are present in one molecule of a compound.
Therefore, CO2 shows that one molecule of carbon dioxide contains one atom of carbon and two atoms of oxygen.
Short names of elements are expressed by symbol.
Symbol denotes one atom of an element.
Symbol of an element indicates its atomic mass.
Symbol of an element contains only one atom of that element.
Short names of elements or compounds are expressed by formula.
The formula of a substance indicates one molecule.
Formula represents the molecular mass of the substance.
Formula represents the number of atoms of the constituent elements present in a molecule.
The molecule of a compound is formed by the combination of two or more atoms.
Atoms in a molecule are held together by chemical affinity.
Such a combination among the atoms does not take place in a haphazard way; while the chemical combination is always held under a definite rule.
1 atom of chlorine combines with 1 atom of hydrogen to form 1 molecule of hydrogen chloride.
1 atom of oxygen combines with 2 atoms of hydrogen to form 1 molecule of water.
1 atom of nitrogen combines with 3 atoms of hydrogen to form 1 molecule of ammonia.
1 atom of carbon combines with 4 atoms of hydrogen to form 1 molecule of methane.
The examples above show that the combining capacity of hydrogen with chlorine, oxygen, nitrogen and carbon is not the same.
One atom of hydrogen combines with one atom of chlorine.
That is, oxygen has double combining capacity of hydrogen.
The combining capacity of an element with other elements is called valency.
The valency of an element is expressed by the number of hydrogen atoms that are combined with or displaced by one atom of that element.
The combining capacity of an element with hydrogen is taken as the unit of valency.
Thus the valency of an element is measured by the number of hydrogen atoms that combine with or are displaced from any compound.
To determine the valency of an element, the valency of hydrogen is taken as 1 unit.
In writing the formula of a compound the valency of the element is to be considered.
The Elements enter into chemical combination to form a compound on the basis of their valency.
We may compare the valency of an element with hands or hooks.
The element with one hand can be compared to something having one valency.
So, an atom of one handed element will combine with another atom of one handed element.
For example, both hydrogen and chlorine are one handed elements.So their valency is also one.
When they combine to form hydrogen chloride, we write them as HCl.
Again, the valency of oxygen is 2 i.e an oxygen atom has two hands.
With its two hands oxygen can catch two monovalent hydrogen atoms.

Sometimes more than one atom combine together to form a group of atoms and this atomic group behaves as a single atom.
Like the atom of an element, they take part as a whole in forming compounds.
This atomic group is called radical.
Sulphate SO24, Carbonate CO23-, Nitrate NO3- etc are the examples of radicals.
Similarly the formula of copper sulphate is Cu = SO4 or CuSO4.
In calcium carbonate the valency of calcium is 2 and that of carbonate is also 2.
Therefore the formula of calcium carbonate is Ca = CO3 or CaCO3.
The valency of iron in iron (III) sulphate is 3;
then what will be the formula of iron (III) sulphate?
If we write Fe = SO4 then one hand of iron remains empty.
But no hand of atom will remain empty in forming a compound.
Then what is to be done?
But in this case there are two hands of an iron atom which remain empty.
Now no blank hand is remaining in iron (III) atom or in the sulphate radical.
Therefore, the formula of iron (III) sulphate will be Fe2(SO4)3.
If you carefully notice these formulas, you will find that each compound has two parts.
Thus, in the above examples, H, Ca, Cu, Fe, etc. are the positive parts and O, Cl, NO3, CO3, SO4, etc are the negative parts.
You will learn more about this in higher classes.
Usually, during the formation of a compound, metallic parts combine with non- metallic elements or radicals.
But in some cases non-metallic elements also combine with themselves to form compounds, such as H2O, HNO3, etc.
